reviewText:
A Scifi Adventure game with an excellent storyline and character interaction. you play as Bishop6, a special agent of the consortium on board a futuristic airplane in a mission to monitor world events and keeping the peace. the whole game is on board that small map that is the Zenlil (airplane) with characters from different countries. the characters themselves seem to escape stereotypes and are great to interact with and they are very well voiced. Jeremy Soule lends his art to the game's soundtrack and that gives it a great immersive atmosphere. highly recommended for Adventure fans

there are RPG/Action elements, but those are very week, and take a second place to the adventure itself.

reviewText:
Consortium is the big boy alternative to the walking simulator.

The first thing that is apparent once you start this game is the degree of bone-crushing depth to the world the developers have created. There are dozens of pages of lore contextualizing every character in the plot, every event in the meta-narrative, and the vision of the future created for this game. This is exactly what people of a certain old school demographic in gaming claim to want in an RPG, but it is instead built upon a mediocre Half Life-esque shooter's skeleton.

I say that, but there is more than one path to progress through the game in which the player doesn't need to engage in combat at all. In fact, Consortium places gunplay in the back seat, leaving the plot to be the driving force. The more active gameplay is, however, still in the car, unlike other games" lauded for their plot but devoid of anything but the simplest interactivity. There is challenge to the combat
recommended: sometimes born of the tight spaces of the ship or the sheer number of enemies players are expected to deal with in one fight. There are also minigames
hoursPlayed: most notably a Missle Command-esque game that
voteText: while not difficult
helpfulPercent: is engaging enough. The point is
votesHelpful: Consortium
votesTotal: while focused on story
votesFunny: does not shun gameplay
commentsCount: or even the fact that it is a game. There are even dialogue options for players who wish there to be no 4th Wall at all.\n\nAnd the subject of dialogue options brings me to the final point in this game's favour: The degree to which the player shapes the story. Consortium is near the level of Obsidian's Alpha Protocol in terms of the permutations each event can have
column16: and each conversation
column17: no matter how trivial
column18: has at least two different potential statements a player can make. This helps immensely in helping the player engage with the rest of the cast
column19: who are all distinct in personality
column20: and for the most part well acted
column21: even if some performances are clearly better than others.\n\nAs I said
column22: Consortium is a big boy alternative to the walking simulator; games that use a focus on story as an excuse to be little more than a film with a few QTEs or childishly easy puzzles. It has RPG-level depth at FPS prices and is not ashamed to go into the absolute minutia about the world it seeks to build for future sequels. If those sequels stay true to this game while improving the more combat-oriented approaches
column23: they would deserve consideration alongside the greats in the Science Fiction genre of video games."

reviewText:
This game is honestly one of the best I've played in a while. Sure there were A LOT of bugs (some of which were game breaking) but they were eventually fixed.

Storywise it starts out making little sense, but as you get into it and begin learning about the characters and kind of the story of the world it starts to make sense and gets more and more interesting. Some events within the game leave you wondering what's going on as much as the characters in the game do...and I don't find that to be a bad thing. This game is one of those that makes a lack of info about the goings on a major part of game and does so to great effect.

It's one of those few where certain characters within are aware they are in a game, and crack jokes about it as result. I love it when games make fun of the fact that they are games. Don't ask me why I don't know.:P

Anyway, Do I recommend this game? Hell yea I do. :)

Also I've played this game via other means for much longer than the 12 minutes Steam says I have.

reviewText:
To me personally this was an incredibly interesting game. It completely subverted my expectations about it when I started playing it. I am so used to getting into a game, listening to 10-15 min of expostition and story content that isn't developed or focused on again until the end, that when I went past that point with CONSORTIUM I was slightly taken aback and realized that this truly is a story focused RPG. And best of all it managed to hold my attention to the story throughout the whole game, and only games with great stories have managed that (sadly, there aren't too many of those). Perhaps this is only a side effect of the fact the game is unexpectedly short, even the story itself doesn't have a good conclusion. It is very much dependant on a sequel, however it is not yet clear if we are going to get one.

The game also has an FPS element to it, which is very much underdeveloped. You have an inventory and equipment system, which you manage throughout the game, so that you will be optimally prepared for combat when the need arises for it. But sadly, that moment doesn't ever come. Not really that is, there are two seperate instances in the game where you can use weapons, in the first one it is clear that the game is pushing you towards the non-violent path. The second one is a bit more mandatory, however you can win that fight simply by waiting it out...

CONSORTIUM reminded me of the times when you are aboard the Normandy in the Mass Effect games and you go around talking to your crewmembers, getting to know them and their story and actually progressing the overall story somewhat. I enjoyed that part in the Mass Effect games, it made me connect with the characters. This game only has that part, but it does it so much better. It would appear they also tried to make the combat part, but given how little importance it has I would imagine they simply didn't have the budget for it.

There are two major disappointments I have with the game. Firstly, its short lenght, and secondly, the present but never developed FPS portion of the game. Seeing all the possibilities this game has on offer I was starting to think this game would be something truly amazing, with a meaning story that made you care about the characters within it, which would connect all the different missions you would embark upon. However, the sad fact is, the game ends before the first mission truly begins.

With that said I can also now reveal that the whole story in the game takes place aboard an airplane (supposedly also a spaceship), and you are fully confined within it throughout the game. All the story elements come from interacting with the people within it (well, almost all), and so it is a good thing that, for the most part, they are well written and voice acted. And with a multitude of dialogue choices and possible story paths there is never a single clear choice to take, there are only the choices you want to make. That is what is most appealing about this game, and it is also what gives it replayability, despite being so heavily story focused. I am a bit disappointed with how it ended and so I won't be replaying it any time soon, only when the sequel comes out (hopefully).

Perhaps the game I envisioned after a couple of hours of play could only have been achieved with a large budget, or perhaps we will get that game after all with multiple sequels of this one. Despite this, CONSORTIUM is worth buying and playing, you just need to be prepared for a fully story focused game and you'll enjoy yourself.

7 / 10

reviewText:
This kind of felt like a High Concept game. Other than a few bugs, I found my first playthrough to be very enjoyable. The story and choices were fun aspects. The universe and technology was really interesting. The theme, while initially was a little challenging to follow, turned out to be very facinating. By the time the game was done, I was begging for more. And that's actually where the problem comes in.

The game invites you to play it over-and-over, but I couldn't. But the game length wasn't long enough to justify it another play through. Even despite the different narrative choices and the mechancal aspects that intertwine the changing story and gameplay, the overarching story will be the same. And it just feels too samey with the other playthroughs.

When the game ended, I was disappointed. It felt like I just finished the very entertaining and scene setting prolog, and it was game over.

Other criticisms include the fourth wall being broken; that just never seems to quite work. I want to get immersed in an RPG-like game, I don't want it to point out Hey. You're playing a video game!" - Let me be a part of this beautiful world. I fullly grasp the attempt at the metaplot. But it just didn't work for me.

There's so much potential in this game.

Ultimately
recommended: with smart game mechinisms. I would absolutely recommend people play it. But due to short narrative
hoursPlayed: unsatisifying cliff-hanger
voteText: and a few other minor things

SHORT REVIEW:

A absolutley wonderful game! I was lucky enough to start playing once the final patch was released, so I experience little to no bugs. CONSORTIUM is based in the year 2042 or something like that. You take control of Bishop 6, which at first, you know nothing about. If you make certain choices, you may never know about his past. I love this game, you can choose from so many paths that will ultimatly lead to one ending and one ending only. Although the ending dissapointed me, because I really don't like waiting for sequels and the way they ended CONSORTIUM leaves the player thinking about his choices that he had made, what he should go back change, and it also leaves the player craving more. Well, atleast it left me craving more. The developers said that the first public release about the next CONSORTIUM is going to be released very soon. You may not be able to tell, but I am VERY excited.

After the first 2 or 3 minutes, I immediatly was set in an immersive world full of characters on a large plane. I enjoyed exploring the crew and was eager to do things. The combat in this game is mediocre but functional, regardless though it hardly matters since it is such a small portion of the game.

SPOILERS AHEAD, but they are required to understand why I am thumbing this down.






I did not mind at all the idea of being an interdimensional traveller who is apparently prophesized to kill a boatload of people. However, the last 15 minutes or so was spent in some kind of... I haven't the slightest clue. Just as I was about to close the game and go to bed, I met John and worked out his predicament. Imagine my dissapointment when it rolls credits. I am not kidding. In fact, the game tells me to specifically break the 4th wall in the sequel, assuming it comes out.
So let's review. A completly immersion breaking ending, asking me to break the 4th wall, ~3 hours of total gameplay, and we have Consortium.

reviewText: For a first installment in a trilogy this game will overwhelm you with game lore. While any gamer can appreciate the devs putting in a good amount of work to create an original world and story for the game, the delivery of the information is done poorly. Your thrown into the game and have to rely on hundreds of articles in a information console to understand what is happening around you which is very frustrating. You'll also be spending about 80% of your time just reading and talking to people and that gets BORING. The game also has this emptiness about it which is very difficult to explain. When you play story rich games you tend to get connected to the characters and the world (like Fallout), but in this game your kind of just going through the motions.

reviewText:
Tl;Dr -  A good game with a lot of potential with interesting writing and world building marred by poor combat.  Unfortunately felt like an incomplete experience that ended far too soon.

Consortium is at heart an adventure/rpg tasking players with finding who the traitor is aboard an airsip and bringing them to justice.  The premise alone sounds interesting but the problem is unlike both RPGs and adventure games items in the game world are essentially just fodder to be recycled to provide power for your armor.  Despite a few times the game tryign to bring attention to certain items, at no point could they be picked up and examined making rifling through people's storage lockers and whatnot pretty pointless.  At no point did I feel like I was a detective trying to get to the bottom is a mystery but rather just going around having a casual chat with murder suspects with no actual ability to dig deeper and snoop around their personal belongings to try to contradict their stories.  As a matter of fact most snooping and gathering of information is taken from a newsfeed console that works like a text based Her Story".  Keywords are used to search for documents and those can be read and new keywords attempted to piece together background and knowledge about characters in the world.

While I liked this in Her Story I found it rather tedious in Consortium.  On the one hand
date: yeah it's nice to have an abundant amount of lore I can read through and learn from but on the other hand...the console isn't very well explained.  Half of the...articles?  Documents?  Whatever I'm supposed to call them are sometimes written as though they were intended to be actual posted texts and other times are written with action cues in them as if they were works of fiction or we were expected to imagine we were watching a video.  This confused tone gave the overall experience a bit of a amateurish vibe as if they weren't quite sure what they really wanted to do with with console research...so they did everything with it.  Also many documents you can search for are obviously meant to be top secret yet anyone and everyone can pull them up with relatively mundane search terms in terminals found in common areas.  I would of rather much of this information be put into the actual game world such as a paper in someone's locker or personal computer or find some notes that lead me to think they have a background in programming
recommended: search under someone's bed and find some other tidbit of information...you know...actually doing stuff with the game world.  Trying to pick up a book or examine something will simply destroy the item and recycle it's energy to power your armor as stated before which...is...mostly pointless.  It seems strange so many junk items are littered around the cramped spaces of the plane when the game has only two or maybe three combat encounters total.\n\nIt also doesn't help that when these sparse combat situations happen the FPS elements are clearly lacking.   The entire experience felt as if this game had come from a past generation where early full 3D FPSes were just stepping out of Wolfenstien 3D's primordial FPS ooze.  Gunplay lacks finesse with mindless enemies running at you guns blazing with no real use of cover or indication that the people you are fighting are real people (a story trope that is hammered in a few times) but rather mindless drones sent at you like so many Doom Imps from times of yore.  You are given essentially a lethal and non lethal method of dealing with enemies but without a system in place to aid in actual non lethal combat it becomes an excercise in tedium.  Instead of methodically taking down enemies trying not to alert the hive
hoursPlayed: you're stuck with a gun having to charge blasts that may or may not take down an enemy down with very little to no feedback as to what's working and why.  Once and enemy is downed you're expected to run over to them and knock them out completely before they manage to get back up lending even more tedium to an already horrible system.  While you are given a generous amount of time to get this done
voteText:
it's still very likely you're going to have to charge into the middle of the battle to try to snag all the enemies at once before they get back up leaving the rest to keep shooting you.  It's an utterly unrewarding experiance they were better off scrapping from the game entirely.

Thankfully the combat is the least important part of the game as you spend most of your time wandering the plane and getting to know it's crew.  This is the meat of the gameplay and is actually done pretty well. You're expected to respond to people in a timely manner and just about everything you say is remembered and has some degree of impact later on giving a pretty good illusion of dealing with real people.  This attention to detail does come back to bite the game as you are often given a limited set of responces and have found on some occations the only sensible option was to stand there awkwardly and say nothing at all.  It's a shame the world itself wasn't given this degree of treatment as I think they could of crafted something rather special.  Each character's opinion of you is tracked seperately though I have yet to actually see this make any kind of major difference other than an indication of if they like you or not.  Only the officers in the ship seem to actually matter as you spend most of your time talking and consulting with them and some Consortium characters only appear for literally a single conversation (yet their approval is still tracked).  Replaying this game is pretty much mandatory as your first run will mostly be spent trying to figure out what the game wants from you and what you can actually do in the world to effect events going on; while this is all very well and good a full third of the game is tedious tutorial things that was interesting only the first time through yet were unskippable since.

In the end my lack of a recommendaiton came down to one thing;  The original demo for Deus Ex.  You see
helpfulPercent: throughout the entire game I kept mentally likening this to Deus Ex.  The RPG/FPS elements
votesHelpful: the clunkiness of how just about everything works yet is not quite clunky enough to make me want to stop playing and
votesTotal: quite frankly
votesFunny: the very similar plot lines.  Deus Ex was one of my favorite games growing up and I remember being impressed by the size and length of it's demo...which was about as long as this entire game. Suffice to say I can't recommend a game that bills itself as a complete product when it's clearly geared to be an episodic release.  I have to admit the game started off on a bad foot with me when I booted it up
commentsCount: was immediatley told of the kickstarter for the "direct continuation".  So I just got this game and now you want funding for chapter two?  The entire plot of the game felt like it was leading to this long and epic storyline that never came.  The game just ended...on a cliffhanger no less.  A cliffhanger whose conclusion they now want me to go fund out of my pocket so I can go buy the second episode of this game.\n\nThis has a lot of potential and I could gladly overlook all of the negative aspects if I felt I was given a complete game.  Unfortunately by the time I first saw those credits roll
column16: my reaction wasn't "Man that was awesome"
column17: it was "You have to be kidding me  All that buildup to the first actual mission in the game it wasn't even IN THE GAME."\n\nPerhaps if the plot was packaged differently and I didn't feel as though I was just railroaded into the next purchase I would be recommending this
column18: but as it stands I just feel disappointed the game fell short of it's potential."

reviewText:
CONSORTIUM is one of my new favorite games. The focus is directed entirely towards areas that most games don't get enough love in. Graphics are passable, and there are some minor glitches, but this game is all about the story. With a playtime of 3-5 hours and a multi-dimensional story line, replay value is through the roof. The short playtime also makes CONSORTIUM fairly easy to play in one sitting, which highlights another of its greatest strengths: the way you influence this world really is entirely based on the decisions you make. Each playthrough you are encouraged to adopt a new approach, and seeing the story all the way through in one sitting allows you to stick to the personality you have assumed. There are only a few instances where combat is required, and even then you can avoid lethal force. Or you can kill everyone, but be prepared for there to be consequences.

In summary:

PROS
Excellent voice acting
Smooth writing
Real impact from your decisions
Replay value 11/10

CONS
Below average graphics
Glitchy, but improving with patches
Lots of looking around in your first playthrough, no guides online that i could find, wiki is incomplete

I really like the game. I have managed to play 19 hours roughly, and damn they were intense. The story has enough twists and turns in the story with elements that may not contribute to the main story but give it context.

You get a lot story context, with things like you are supposed to be a combat specialist, and due to this you can use the virtual training program. People are suprised when you don't know about weaponry and what country made equiptment. It makes sense. That is why I love this game. But it at the same time manages to break the fourth wall 3-5 times intentionally in a good meaningfully way, with a good amount of plot twists that make no sense else where, but due to the story delivery due make sense to the nth degree. But it for the story,

reviewText:
CONSORTIUM is exactly the kind of game that I have wanted for years and yet it misses the mark so badly. You find yourself as a player transported into the body of someone in another dimension (yes just like Nomad Soul) who is kind of a heavy gunner type assassin for the crew of a high tech Bowing747. The idea for the game seems to have been to throw crises at the crew and allow the player in an interactive fiction type way to be an instrumental part of the crews survival, with a combination of free roaming, actions on the ship, dialogue and if the player wants to, combat.

Your experience here is short without any completed story arcs, not that the game is long enough to do a good one. The poor writing starts when you are thrown into a world without any boot strapping to tell you anything about what is going on. I only became comfortable with the organisation I was working for and even knew what my character's role on the ship was after doing some reading outside of the game, after my first play through. The dialogue is poor, mainly because the characters lack real depth, the events in the game are pulled right from badly written 90's films (Under Siege 1992). Combat is clunky, when there is combat, and the combat simulator missions are unfinished and not, fun.

This game has so many bugs! And I played the 1.2 Master Edition which is a re-release, as the first version contained a lot of bugs. CONSORTIUM does not feel like a well tested or polished experience. This really needed more time in development. The component parts are here, but it hasn't been crafter or polished into a fine product.
3/5

reviewText: A beautifully well-written game. It throws you in the deep end plot-wise, but that is actually a plus for this game as you work out just what kind of situation in. Quickly into the plot, it develops into mysterious and, for once, actually believable mystery game. The one (or two, depending on your choices, I hear) proper shooting sequence has mechanics decent enough to make it enjoyable and I assume it's a taste test for the sequel, which will likely have more. Kudos to the developer for making the mystery cohesive and giving the player a truly stumping series of events. I only got it right because I noticed the culprit doing some dodgy acts before the investigation. The culprit was believable and I did not find myself irritated by any cliches. The plotline thankfully avoids many, many cliches. It is also brilliantly well acted, and the variance of accents really gives it a feeling of a futuristic, almost united world. The plot also reminds me of 1984, and gives the player perfect reason to support any of the factions (or neither, like me). I find most games flop when they try to write as intricate plot as this, either falling into cliche or simply being way too over its head to be coherent or well written. This game, however, does it well and gets a high reccomendation from me. A little short, but still well worth the investment. Can't wait for the sequel.\n\nBy the way, your choices change a lot. Unlike most games *cough cough* Telltale's Game of Thrones *cough cough*, every choice is significant and you also know when a significant decision must be made. You understand the severity of the events at all time and the game throughout is very intense. I'm so glad this game did its choices and consequences right.

reviewText:
Consortium is able to be a game world that is realized on a scale that is able to immerse the player wholly. Now, getting off the Webster-Merriam high horse, Consortium is able to deliver a world that feels real and right.

This is a believable world with as much character as any world should have if it is to be as much a character as any other. It does not wait for you to give it the green light to move forward. The universe will continue on whether you're ready or not.

The cast of this game, as well, truly feels alive and they interact realistically. When you're not watching, they still have full agendas, talking with people and moving around, doing their jobs. When you talk to them, they are able to feel fleshed out and they react realistically as if you have existed in this world.

In a nutshell, this game is a must-play for those who love story and conversation as well as being able to immerse themselves for a few hours in a soon to be continued game world.

reviewText:
To start:  I love this game.  But, it can be little rough at the moment.

I was a backer on this game during Kickstarter, I was very intrigued at the setting, art style, and gameplay premise.  It seemed to be a unique take and full of great new ideas.  In this respect the game did not dissapoint me.  The weighted crew interactions are very well done and I found the voice work to be pretty good.  The first core gameplay centers around conversations with crew members of the Zenlil, navigating dialog trees to increase or decrease approval with different crew members and opening up new lines of inquiry and knowledge.  The second is exploring the Zenlil craft and interacting with it, though in this game it is a bit limited by what the scripting allows.  Third is the FPS combat, and in my particular playthrough it took a backseat, though depending in your actions you could get a lot more.

The story and plot started off well and became more and more intrigueing as the game progressed.  It takes place in the future, where your psyche has taken possession of a soldier on the combat aircraft Zenlil of the international Consortium.  Your mind has been sent forward to this realm through a special satellite system presented as a game.  But is it really a game?  What are the true motives of those who control the system?  And what might happen if you try to test the limits of that control?  Play to find out.

The world of Consortium is surprisingly deep, and there is an in-game knowledge center for those who really like to dig into the lore.  Multiple in-game hints also indicated that there is an ARG that links to the world that provides more background.  By the end I found myself with a few Oh Wow" moments that really have me looking forward to the second Consortium game.

Now for a few negatives.  Despite the tremendous quality of the game from a small indie developer

reviewText:
I really like the game. I have managed to play 19 hours roughly, and damn they were intense. The story has enough twists and turns in the story with elements that may not contribute to the main story but give it context.

Example: You talk to a crew member, and find out that they have a deep friendship with blah blah crew member. They then defend said member in a disagreement that splits the crew, this actually now makes sense.

You get a lot story context, with things like you are supposed to be a combat specialist, and due to this you can use the virtual training program. People are suprised when you don't know about weaponry and what country made equiptment. It makes sense. That is why I love this game. But it at the same time manages to break the fourth wall 3-5 times intentionally in a good meaningfully way, with a good amount of plot twists that make no sense else where, but due to the story delivery due make sense to the nth degree. But it for the story,

reviewText:
Undertale got popular for promoting itself as a critique of irrational violence, but for me its approach was done first in Consortium.

It was so refreshing to have real, demonstrable moral options for your protagonist's actions. The pathway to pacifism is not obvious either: like Undertale it takes careful consideration of the motives and background of your antagonists. Unlike Undertale the lore of Consortium is deeply and richly detailed, with pages upon pages of news reports, intelligence analysis, character briefings, transcriptions, etc etc.

Imagine if Undertale grew up. That's Consortium.

reviewText: Consortium is a sci-fi'ish game set in the near future (there's more to it than that, but that's the easiest way to classify it). You play as Bishop 6 quite literally. It's a meta sort of thing, though that's not spoilers.\n\nThe Good: I loved the plot and the character interaction. It reminded me a lot of Mass Effect 2 in that regard, but with more life to it because people aren't always in the exact same spots. The graphics are nothing special, but they do fit with the art style. I loved that every choice in this game seemed to matter (we'll have to wait until part 2 to see how much), but it was nice to see immediate consequences and not just a change in an arbitrary karma bar llike some games. Yes, I'm looking at you Mass Effect 2. Speaking of a sort of karma bar, there isn't one, at least not one visible to the player and I for one loved it for that. As long as it's done well having no number attached to your actions that the player can see makes it mroe immersive and stops the player from counting karma". The choices make a difference and aren't just things referenced in one line of dialogue lateer and forgot. A lot of your choices determine who lives and who dies
date: a thing most games are afraid to do and save for the last minutes of a game.\n\nThe Bad: Glitches. There are quite a few
recommended: but there's nothing that can't be fixed fairly easily. Aside from the game crashing when you alt-tab
hoursPlayed: there's no crash related bugs I've encountered. I run two 660 ti's in sli so I fully expected crashed and other stupid stuff

helpfulPercent: but I think the replayability makes up for it. Going through the game again with vastly different choices should have a huge effect on the story and make your game completely different.\n\nThe Ugly; I don't really have anything for this section. There aren't any really bad bugs
votesHelpful: at least nothing on the scale of bluescreening or anything that severe.\n\nIn summary I loved this game. It is a little weird

Haven't finished the game yet, but I want to write this review to say this game deserves more attention, I have been waiting for a game like this to come out. True there are glithches but with so many options the game give you to solves a problem it is not a surprise. But if you can live with a few bugs it is still a good game. The story is great;

reviewText:
This game is unlike anything I've ever played.  It has stylings of other branched-dialogue games, like Mass Effect or KOTOR.  The difference is the extent to which the game respects and reacts to your choices as a player.  Your possible decisions are many, and they will change the way characters treat you, and the outcome of the game.

The world is also beautifully realized, with rich (optional) lore for your enjoyment.  After reading a small chunk of the available lore, I had a better understanding of the game world, and found myself more engaged for it.

One thing that may turn off some players is that the game will not hold your hand.  It will allow you to make mistakes and fail, which makes succeess all the more rewarding.

I recommend giving this sleeper a try - you may be pleasantly surprrised.

reviewText: Consortium reminds me of the old school story telling games that you'd spend months or even years replaying. This titles depth caught me by surprise as I missed the hype and only caught the game once it hit steam but even ignoring the then omnious warning from the developers about the games bugs and to avoid purchase, I decided to leap in and take a look, I mean, the devs seemed dedicated so why not, right? And now that most of those are sorted, the game is a real gem.\n\nI was delighted with a well scripted, although with some sometimes flat voice acting (perhaps intended?) well laid out plot options and some pretty amazing gameplay during the FPS style scenes. But it does not stop there either, there are so many differing gameplay elements built into the game and melded together so gracefully it's hard to not lace this review with spoilers but I will behave myself and let you enjoy the game for yourself.

reviewText:
CONSORTIUM is an odd beast. I can honestly say I had a great time with it, and can tell that the developers put a lot of time, effort, and heart into getting this indie creation to function like it does. I'd compare it favorably to the sections in MASS EFFECT where you just chat it up with your crew on the Normandy, learn a little bit about every one, affect their lives in little ways.

In CONSORTIUM, the crew is a lot less diverse (sometimes, I had trouble telling them apart), but the reactivity is absolutely fantastic. Going through the achievements, I can see so many different outcomes to choices that I made half-heartedly at the time. There's a lot of opportunity for replayablilty here. That is if you're on-board with the game's premise of spending 4-5ish hours getting to know its cast of characters in a confined flying command center.

If you love the dialog/choice-heavy sections of modern RPGs, here's a great little game that's built entirely around that. As someone who always puts points into charisma in RPGs (I know, I know), CONSORTIUM was right up my alley.

It's definitely not perfect. There are entire systems (inventory and ammo management) built around its very clunky combat mechanics, but I can only think of a few times when you have occasion to use your gun. You'll probably see more combat in the combat training scenario than in the rest of the game combined. It gives the impression of a game that's trying to check a box" rather than make it a key part of the experience. It is a-okay to not have combat in a game like this. When CONSORTIUM was at its best
date: it reminded me of TITANIC: ADVENTURE OUT OF TIME. No combat

reviewText: I just have to give a shout-out to this as a hidden gem. Picture a low-budget indie production of Star Trek, as a game where the whole thing plays out on the ship. It's short, it's buggy as HELL, it comes with a massive cliffhanger ending smack in the middle of the story, and at most it's worth getting for 50% off -- but it's a good ride while it lasts. Pretty unique. There's a surprising flexibility to what you can accomplish with what's given, and if Consortium 2 is ever made I would totally be on board with that.\n\nAll that said, play it on Easy. The combat, rare though it is, is BONKERS hard, at least if you're trying not to go full lethal.

reviewText:
An amazing game with a great story.

Cons:
- Shooter (shooting) elements seem somewhat poor. The ideas are ok, their execution... not so much.
- Part 2 again needs crowdfundning and boy we need that game out already. This story needs conclusion!
- Performance problems?

Pros:
- Everything else, really. As in...
- ...really, REALLY great plot, characters, interactions between them, their agendas;
- Amazing atmosphere. I mean it: it's one of the most immersive games I've played;
- Did I mention how great are the atmosphere and the plane crew? You care for characters, you feel for them.
- Very good pacing.
- Great character visual design, very good plane design.
- Nice cartoon-ish" graphics.
- Even though the game ends pretty much with "To be continued"

reviewText: I cannot recommend this game as I encountered a game breaking bug about an hour or so into the plot. Other than that, I was having fun up to this point although this game felt more linear than I was expecting, for instance you can't even initiate dialogs with people the plot doesn't want you talking to right at that moment which was interfering with my immersion.

reviewText: It took me a little while to get past Consortium's fairly ugly, Reboot-esque graphics, but I'm glad I did, because it's a pretty interesting game. In some ways, the game feels like a tutorial level for a bigger game - the game teaches you how to manage your health and armor and use one of five weapons, with loading screen tutorial texts to match, but there's almost no actual combat in the game, amounting to a single optional firefight and some VR training missions. But it also uses this to have a somewhat interesting setting - the entire game takes place on an airship on the way to your next mission, and along the way you deal with a locked room murder mystery and unearth conspiracies. The gameplay is mostly dialogue-based with occasional bits of action, and the dialogue offers enough variety to highly encourage multiple playthroughs with the amount of choices you get and secrets to find. The dialogue is made interesting by the fact that rather than just breaking the fourth wall, Consortium doesn't really have a 4th wall to begin with, and the player is recognized in the game as a person using the game (described in-universe as a software that allows you to view the future through someone else's eyes) to control the main character in the future. This also ties into a pretty extensive ARG that leads up to the game for those who find themselves wanting more of the game's lore, and if you don't want to play the entire ARG there's a free DLC package that gives you all of the documents to clue you in, but it's a pretty substantial read, running several hundred pages of PDFs. The game can be enjoyed without ever acknowledging the ARG, however.\n\nConsortium is a game that feels like a smaller part of a bigger game while still holding its own as a standalone experience, and the next game, Consortium: The Tower, is currently in development and will presumably start off where this game ends. At the base price of $15 I'd consider Consortium to be a decent purchase, but at its current sale price of $1.50 I don't see any reason not to give it a try if you're into dialogue-based stories.

reviewText: The most interesting game I have played all year. A first person RPG set in a reasonably interesting universe with an Assassin's Creed-esque meta-layer that is handled in a much more interesting manner. The story feels incredibly reactive to what you do and the path I took felt natural in a way that no other game has. Short (~3 hours on first run) but seems designed for multiple playthroughs. First in a planned trilogy, can't wait for the second game.

reviewText:
Short In Depth Game Analysis:
Consortium is an indie game that mainly focuses on time travel and conspiracies.You take control of Bishop-06 an consortium officer that is on the ship Zenlil that travels to England,As soon as you wake up from sleeping things are just going to get worse, as well, one of your crew members gets killed and then continues to mess with the system of the ship.Its your job to catch the murderer before things go much much worse

Story:
The game has a story that mainly sticks around the ship and its members. The story is about a agent that travels to england and then when things go worse he investigates the situation. it just gets more tense near the end 10/10

Gameplay:The gameplay is basic FPS one, including one new addition to scrap metals and things to create energy to use your suit's abilities 6/10

Graphics:
The graphics are pretty much nothing new, they are easy to handle even with a bad computer, and they are mainly a bit spiky at some aspects. 7/10
Overall:
The game is pretty much perfect when it comes to storytelling but not when it comes to graphics preformance and gameplay. Overall score is around 7/10, but still, you should play it

reviewText:
**Worst Indie Game Experience to date**

The fact they want $14 is a hilarious joke, you get 3 hours of gameplay at it if you go REALLY slow. I got this when it was FREE and feel like I need to be compensated for wasting my time on my horrible Source-engine simulator.

I normally just do TLDR reviews so see below:


Pros:
-None

Cons:
-Horrible scripting

-Buggy as all get out, I had several instances where the storyline bugged because a trigger I walked over would replay a conversation between various NPCs I'd done an hour ago

-Horrendous animations

-Only one instance where you actually shoot a gun

-Again, the pricetag.


To sum up, this game is NOT an RPG, it's NOT a simulator, it's definitely Indie but beyond that this plays like a couple of teenagers pulled up the Source SDK over their summer break and cranked this joke of a game out.

And guess what popped up as soon as I launched the game after getting it for FREE? A bloody Hey back us up on KICKSTARTER FOR CONSORTIUM: THE TOWER!"

I've never felt like contacting Valve/Steam over being ripped off
date: but if I'd bought this game for $15 when it came out I would've seriously taken it up with Valve to get my money back. You get 3hours of gameplay
recommended: there's no point in replaying it to see if you could've "Done things differently" like in KOTOR or Mass Effect.\n\nSimply put
hoursPlayed: don't waste your time."

reviewText:
I initially had no expectations when trying out this game. I was so fortunate to get it for free at a promotional weekend, and I'm ever so grateful for discovering it. The game, that has roots in a kickstarter campaign, might not look like much from the screenshots alone, but it's one hell of a ride I haven't felt since back in the old days of videogames.

The game has many ways of creating a personalized outcome of the story, so the replayability seems fairly decent. Sure there are tedious moments (optional mind you) of reading through the archives of the ship, but the game still managed to keep me interested with exploring, sidequesting and actually getting involved with the story that has a little bit of everything. A mixed vibe of Deus Ex, The Matrix and The Twilight Zone in fact.

The voice acting is great, as well as the filmic soundtrack that accompanies the game. The graphics are somewhat expected from something that is crowdfunded, but the style is fresh and a pleasure to look at. You'll be surprised how the Source engine is still kicking, even after all the years Valve has left it (and their videogames) in the dust.

A congratulation is in order to the developers for a fantastically well-made game. This is a definite recommendation from me, and I can't wait for the next two installments in the trilogy of Consortium.

reviewText:
I think this game has amazing potential, but mediocre application. If you play the game for the first time, you'll be ridicously excited about the different possibilities in the game. You'll enjoy it. Perhaps so much that this will be worth the price of the game alone. However...

If you replay it to discover the differences in the game, and try to get a different outcome, you'll realize you've been cheated into thinking that all these possibilities were there, when in fact they were illusionary.  (It's as if the Stanley Parable only had dead ends in all but one path) Your role in any replay will vary only very slighty from your first playthrough, and let's face it: the value of this game is the freedom and your role in the story.

Summary: This game could've been revolutionary, instead its passable and forgettable. I would not recommend it to anyone, but also hope they continue the franchise with major improvements.

reviewText:
I really like the approach of making the user essentially a character in the story. It's a unique perspective for the game to take. The story is solid, the characters are interesting, and I like what they are doing here conceptually.

In practice, it doesn't make for a great game. It wants you to read through exhaustive articles to pick up little bits of information. It wants you to replay the same game multiple times in order to pick up on a reasonable chunk of the story and content. It can be confusing to navigate the ship when they frantically yell at you to go to some area with an unclear location. Other than to appear Mass Effect-like, I don't know why they chose to utilize a first person engine. The combat and inventory are exceedingly clunky. Going with an RPG style or even menu based system would probably fit the overall game better.

It's interesting and I'm glad that I played it, but I wouldn't recommend it to others. Without a smoother gameplay experience, I'm not eager to play the sequel to continue the story when it comes out.

reviewText:
Game is fully voice acted, a role playing title, that lets you role play your bishop in a number of different ways, which in turn makes it a good role playing game. The combat parts are a bit meh, but executed well enough and with a deliberate choise behind them, which makes it challenging to try and either incapacitate opponents or kill them.

What really makes the game for me is a very interesting backstory and universe upon which you are inserted into. Plus the secret hints you can find lying around in various clues about the universe in which you are pushed into. A very neat mystery.

So if you are into a sci-fi detective/exploration story i would definitely recommend this game.

reviewText: Without question, this has been one of my most enjoyed entertainment experiences to date. The story is excellent, the world is well fleshed out, the characters are unique and believable... Its like a Telltale Games adventure but you get to jump in guns blazing to be the hero at times as well. I'm so hopeful that the sequel will come around because I'm enthralled enough that I need closure on this, and just more games like this in general. I could not reccommend this highly enough to other gamers who value an engrossing experience. There were a few graphical glitches and gameplay/physics bugs that would normally have been a bit infuriating but, in this context, I just didn't care; they couldn't detract from the rest of the wonderful time spent in this gem of a game.\n\n[Edit] I've just finished a second playthrough and now I'm even more in love. Discovered so many extra details and options. The sequel can't come soon enough! [/edit]

reviewText:
Well, at least its got cards...

Terrible gameplay, graphics from the late 90's and awful performance.

Interaction with NPCs and objects works basically on and off. If a door opens once, don't expect it to open again by interacting with it from the exact same angle; go take a walk, come back and it will (hopefully) then open. Same with NPCs, even worse when you have to either incapacitate or heal them. Weapons behave weirdly and not very dynamic; the whole combat system doesn't feel very intuitive and up for the challenge; add to that the fact that this game is so poorly optmized that playing it gives me headaches.

Also, the lack of a map with objective marks makes for a hellishly infuriating experience, especially on missions where time is key for completion. How the hell am I supposed to know where all the rooms in the ship are by name? How can I know where I'm heading to? Also, how am I supposed to know I'm some sort of time traveler" if there's no background explanation and no hint about it?

Some of the dialog choices makes no sense
date: and seem to be more appropriate for end game rather than beginning.\n\nIt's a real shame that this game didn't really take off and they're basically giving it away at just about every indie game website. It had potential
recommended: and someone did put a lot of work into the story
hoursPlayed: and also the voice acting is quite decent.\n\nIt kind of angers me when part of a team puts in all the work

reviewText: This game feels like it was specifically designed to torture autistic people. There is constant flashing, flickering, and shaking of the screen which, as far as I could find, cannot be turned off. While you're talking to one character, multiple conversations are going on the background so you can't hear a word anyone is saying. There are subtitles available, but they are horribly coded - the entirety of what the person is saying flashes on the screen all at once, then disappears line by line BEFORE the character is even finished reading the line. I get the idea of throwing you into a situation you're not prepared for and having you figure out what's going on, Quantum Leap style, but the game doesn't even tell you what most of the controls are. At one point, my quest flashed up on the screen, while at the same time, FOUR other pieces of text information flashed up, AND there was a disembodied voiceover telling me what I should be doing (on top of which, the background was occasionally flashing with a painful white light). Unable to process any of that since I didn't know what to focus on, suddenly ALL the informaion disappeared (other than the painful flashing, of course). I still had no idea what my quest was or even how to find out. Nothing is explained until way too late - fine for storytelling, BAD NEWS for gameplay. I could only tolerate about 30 minutes of this before I could feel myself going into sensory overload and had to turn it off. I've been playing video games my whole life and never once have I had that happen.\n\nIt's possible there is a great story and a really interesting game in there, but if you have ANY kind of sensory issues whatsoever, don't go anywhere near this one unless you're prepared to have a meltdown or a seizure, because you will.

reviewText: I have only played through the game once all the way through, but I really enjoyed it. It was very personal and intimate, most of it focusing on dramatic moments between multiple people in the crew, and it also featured choices that were organic and natural, to the point were I made game-changing desicions a few times without ever realising I was making a choice. reviewText:
Well I don't have a lot to say about this Title, it has OK Graphics, So/So Shootermechanics and a Good RPG System. The Lore is extensive and the decisions you make are plentyful and yield high impact on Gameplay and your Surroundings. For someone who has not played it's Predecessor the Lore is a little Hard to understand but if you are Willing to listen and read you get dragged into a Lorerich Universe.

The Game is very well thought throug, it has a lot of Secrets to find, although the Surrounding you can explore is limited.

This one is very very Hard to recommend without spoiling, but this should be for you if:

- You like an immersive Gameplay
- You like reading lots and lots of lore.
- You like to be praised if you do something well and scolded if you're acting evil.

You will dislike the Game if:

-You're looking for a shooter
-You're looking for next-Gen-Hardcore Graphics
-You're looking for a Falloutclone. (It has nothing in Common although both have weapons and dialouge, this one is wayy heavier on the dialouge and Choices)
-You like scanning for life signs (if you play it, you'll get this joke)

I enjoyed my Consortium Expirience and I am looking forward to the next Episode.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I am really enjoying this game so far.  The game feels verrry deep.  I question everything :)  We'll see if that bears out as the plot is uncovered.  Nice to see an RPG that actually encourages deep role play, instead of just focusing on stats gear.

8/10

EDIT: Found more content. I would rate this as the cultural successor to the movie Donnie Darko, and all the media that entailed. 11/10

reviewText: Edit: I made a stupid choice in the beginning of the game which made my progression through the game entirely without combat, but such is my playstyle and I enjoy replayability. The dev commented on my bug report within 6 hours as well, which is certainly encouraging. Still recommend this game, and suggest to make mistakes and see it through so you actually feel the effects of your actions.\n\nPretty fun so far, though I've managed to do something that makes the game pretty much impossible to complete. I'll look for a place to report bugs and see if someone else has had the same issue. No crashes though and I like the amount of stuff I'm able to do. This is the kind of experience I was hoping for when I played Heavy Rain (disappointingly) way back when it first came out on PS3.

reviewText:
This game is shockingly short, but the storytelling more than makes up for it. In just 5 hours of gameplay, I actually beat the game while realizing that there is much more inside of it...

The music is outstanding, the character voices are wonderful (Aside from a certain blabbermouth, but I think that's intentional) and the only major problem I had with most of the scenes was them waving their hands in the air as if they are constantly typing on a holo-screen.

For five hours of gameplay, I successfully saved lives, and failed at the plot. But there are no bad choices in this game (Aside from standing still under fire...) and my best choice is rating it 8.5/10.


I just wish I realized it was a trilogy before I bought it...


SIDE EDIT: Just remembered, this was made in Source, the next is gonna be Unreal, just like how much they pulled out of the first engine.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
-THIS IS NOT AN EARLY ACCESS REVIEW-

This game is something really great. I've waited for the final release of the game, for all the bugs to fix, and, unlike the other weird people, I reviewed the final release the game. Generally gameplay reminds me of System Shock 2, bit of Deus Ex and bit of first Half Life too. Speaking of Half Life, and fighting by the way, all the game can be finished without firing a single bullet - conversation is of course the most important thing here -  or of course you can fight your way through the game, and doing that be carefull when you firing grenades - you are in a pretty BIG aircraft, you know what I mean and yes - I tried this once and almost flew away through the hole i made :d Combat is though. Even on a easiest level, it's still challenging. But, I am sure that the great characters, interesting plot with many things to discover, (not through the first gameplay - i've played two times and everytime the game was MUCH different as I was choosing other options and deeds), a LOT of dialogues with a perfect voice acting and dubbing will convince you to check this out.

PS. I don't care about how the game looks, Consortium is poor in graphics but pretty rich in other stuff. Go play Far Cry 3 if you want good looking games and don't even try this in that case.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The first great game of 2014! This game has personality and it shows in every interaction. The scope of the game may be small but the details keep you wanting more and many of the actions you take really feel like they are impacting the rest of the game. Like the great RPGs of old you can complete the game without killing anyone and be a saint to your crew mates or a silent killing machine feared and respected by everyone you come across. The only downsides are that combat can get clunky at times and the color blue is a bit overused. Imaginitive and unique Consortium is a fantastic fist person experience that can be played over and over again.

reviewText:
I have suspected this for a while, but I can conclued that the best games do in fact come from Canada.

The ending hyped me for the possible sequel immediatly. I love this game's atmosphere. Its plot line can be compared to that of Telltale's The Walking Dead, it was ultimately linear, but your choices did matter. I would even go as far as to say the developers surpassed Telltale here. Screw Metascore this time. This game has the potential to be at least as great as Bioware's Mass Effect or Valve's own Half-Life.

I can only semi-complain about the cliff-hanger at the end, so I must beg the developers to please actually release a second part, (Half-Life 3 anytime soon, Valve?) I feel as if this concept can be greatly expanded upon.

reviewText:
Just got done playing CONSORTIUM after picking it up in the humble bundle, I heard good things about it and this is what I took away from my experience.

Great-Characters, pacing, atmosphere
The characters are written well with their own motives and quirks, without being transparent enough to feel like an NPC. Pacing of these interactions and the overall plot are not bad at all, and when combined with the setting deliver a game you can jump into and feel hooked. I personally enjoyed the voiceacting and sound design.

Alright-Play length and amount of content to experience on a single playthrough leaves something to be desired, don't blow your horn about a trilogy if they're all going to be this quick and rely on multiple playthroughs to deliver full circle. Content is one thing, double handling gets old after awhile. I appreciate that we have many choices, but some of them lack follow through if you play certain types of characters. Sometimes there is no foothold for a player with too much intuition that will scour out of the way areas.

Lore dumps-the lore contained in this game is handcrafted and certainly interesting. The only problem outside of limited audio broadcasts/conversations is that if you want to experience any of it-have fun reading codex lore dumps in the menu. No offense but it was more fun to fly by the seat of my pants than do that and try to figure anything out, which seems to be a huge waste. Why gate so much great stuff behind one of the dullest interactions in your game?

Plain bad-Shooting, Inventory management, sense of progression, jaggy shadows

This is a game worth playing but it feels at times if it is grasping for too many things to have that feature list" that tends to accompany recent steam releases. The shooting is just plain bad(especially if you want to play non-killing)
date: the hud sucks for it. If you want to play a decent shooter don't come into Consortium expecting even that. To make the matter worse any inventory management feels like it is there just to be there. Most of the items I encountered had no practical use inside the story
recommended: and anytime I did use a weapon/ammo/armor it was unintuitive
hoursPlayed: a huge hassle
voteText: and most of all not even fun. These two areas need some polish or even to be redone completely if you want to really tout them as cornerstones of the gameplay experience.\n\nWhich leads to my next point-progression. At the end of the day I felt like I made a difference
helpfulPercent: and was a set piece for some cool stuff. Even though I kept being swept along to the next issue there were a few "AHA" experiences in the plot or character interactions which left me wanting more. But you still feel very gated off from what is really happening
votesHelpful: with few avenues to approach it in an otherwise very thoughtful and ambitious setup.\n\nAlso the shadow jaggies are downright terrible
votesTotal: expect them to be a bit jarring even if you have a nicer PC.\n\nMy final comments will be aimed at the developer review-you need to decide on what you want and get it right the first time
votesFunny: and budget the appropriate timelines and resources to it. There is a vocal audience that bought into this game when it released
commentsCount: and you can tell they felt let down by the compromises and changes you made to the content and schedule. I can believe how buggy the initial playthroughs probably were. You can't look back and say "Well I should have done it that way" or "Well we have this awesome system
column16: but the way it was presented in the first game didn't suit it well"\n\nI don't say this to be harsh
column17: but to let you know those were both areas of your responsibility during game production
column18: and to say it didn't work or wasn't presently appropriately falls on you. It is easy to say how you would change past design decisions or player encounters at the end of the day
column19: for obvious reasons. Perhaps a wiser approach towards future projects would be to set clear
column20: concise goals on how to approach past issues while being mindful of what worked well."

reviewText:
I found this game to be mostly impressive. You take the roll of Bishop 6, a soldier serving on a ship trying to find out what is going on.
The game is good because there is no cutscenes to interrupt you, you stay in the same location, a very good dialogue mechanic and a very good story with alot of betrayel.
Honestly, it feels like Game of Thrones because of the betrayels and the turn-ups but its differant, its more sci-fi and takes place in the world where we live in the future. And the team names are names from chess which is ok.
Good game, neat graphics, good combat system and a very Rich story.
I'd put this game 10/10.
Hoping CONSORTIUM: The Tower comes out on steam.

reviewText:
Gods Damn.
Just completed my first run through and this is a great forray into the realm of how interactive and engaging the art of videogames can be.
It is not as polished as other games attempting similar, but for what it attempts, it does it well and is absolutely worth picking up (Especially when it is on sale).
The story for a first timer probably takes about 3-4 hours on the easiest setting.
All of the side missions are easy enough to do and add to the main story.
The music is really good.  I mean, really good.  The end credits for whatever reason remind, at times, of A New Hope or various serious 80s SciFi scores.

It is not an action game though, so don't expect it to be Half-Life.  It is a story game first with rare, brief moments of light FPS-ing.

The only real cons I might have for it are;

Unless you're really in to the lore, you probably aren't going to sit through reading all the data logs in the game, and their bricks of text, that aren't particularly pleasant to sort through when you are looking for something.

If you are sensitive to screen static, it is purposely part of the story and experience, and while not distracting, it is not exactly subtle either.

Manual Save/Load system is quite functional, but a touch clunky.

reviewText:
Just got done playing CONSORTIUM after picking it up in the humble bundle, I heard good things about it and this is what I took away from my experience.

Great-Characters, pacing, atmosphere
The characters are written well with their own motives and quirks, without being transparent enough to feel like an NPC. Pacing of these interactions and the overall plot are not bad at all, and when combined with the setting deliver a game you can jump into and feel hooked. I personally enjoyed the voiceacting and sound design.

Alright-Play length and amount of content to experience on a single playthrough leaves something to be desired, don't blow your horn about a trilogy if they're all going to be this quick and rely on multiple playthroughs to deliver full circle. Content is one thing, double handling gets old after awhile. I appreciate that we have many choices, but some of them lack follow through if you play certain types of characters. Sometimes there is no foothold for a player with too much intuition that will scour out of the way areas.

Lore dumps-the lore contained in this game is handcrafted and certainly interesting. The only problem outside of limited audio broadcasts/conversations is that if you want to experience any of it-have fun reading codex lore dumps in the menu. No offense but it was more fun to fly by the seat of my pants than do that and try to figure anything out, which seems to be a huge waste. Why gate so much great stuff behind one of the dullest interactions in your game?

Plain bad-Shooting, Inventory management, sense of progression, jaggy shadows

This is a game worth playing but it feels at times if it is grasping for too many things to have that feature list" that tends to accompany recent steam releases. The shooting is just plain bad(especially if you want to play non-killing)
date: the hud sucks for it. If you want to play a decent shooter don't come into Consortium expecting even that. To make the matter worse any inventory management feels like it is there just to be there. Most of the items I encountered had no practical use inside the story
recommended: and anytime I did use a weapon/ammo/armor it was unintuitive
hoursPlayed: a huge hassle
voteText: and most of all not even fun. These two areas need some polish or even to be redone completely if you want to really tout them as cornerstones of the gameplay experience.\n\nWhich leads to my next point-progression. At the end of the day I felt like I made a difference
helpfulPercent: and was a set piece for some cool stuff. Even though I kept being swept along to the next issue there were a few "AHA" experiences in the plot or character interactions which left me wanting more. But you still feel very gated off from what is really happening
votesHelpful: with few avenues to approach it in an otherwise very thoughtful and ambitious setup.\n\nAlso the shadow jaggies are downright terrible
votesTotal: expect them to be a bit jarring even if you have a nicer PC.\n\nMy final comments will be aimed at the developer review-you need to decide on what you want and get it right the first time
votesFunny: and budget the appropriate timelines and resources to it. There is a vocal audience that bought into this game when it released
commentsCount: and you can tell they felt let down by the compromises and changes you made to the content and schedule. I can believe how buggy the initial playthroughs probably were. You can't look back and say "Well I should have done it that way" or "Well we have this awesome system

column17: but to let you know those were both areas of your responsibility during game production

reviewText:
Great game. Has that Quantum Leap Feel to it. Minus the Fact that your controlling another person via remote control for the most part.

The game is worth it for a laugh and doesn't spoon feed you anything, that you should know while taking over the person your in. You get the control prompts and tool tips required to navigate the hud.
But, anything else is for the most part you are so and so and you got to fill in the blank with out Al or Ziggy giving you any help you would expect from the TV series.

You have to play the game like you attempting to solve a mystery, and remember everything as best as possible. You will find if you play a certain way you won't catch any one off guard because your taking the role of a new transfer to a ship. Clearly you don't know anything the first time playing, and so helps soften the blow for your first time playing through.

Is the game worth it. Yes if you enjoy reading into things and documenting things personally yourself.

Get the game and Enjoy the Talkies and Virtual Simulator Challenges.

reviewText:
A great game for those that love interactive stories in their games. Good writing, good characterization, and good voice acting come together to make a solid piece of video game storytelling. There are plenty of permutations in the story to justify multiple playthroughs, and your choices genuinely affect the way the story plays out. Considering the fact that there are so few games like this that focus on player choice, it's good to not only see it released, but to see that it is done very well, and in a unique way. For this alone, I would recommend the game.

Though the game contains combat, there isn't very much of it. This is a bit odd considering how much detail they tried to put into the system. In the higher difficulty levels, individual parts of your suit and body can be damaged, and you can repair/heal those specific parts. There's even an inventory system, wherein you can trade energy (which is used for repairs and energy weapons) for physical space to carry guns, ammo, etc.

Despite this level of detail, it isn't particularly polished. The AI spews fire everywhere while running around like headless chickens, and the inventory system is more annoying than it's really worth. The creators of the game either had a grander vision than they were able to actually execute, or they are just trying to establish the skeleton of the combat system for the future titles.

Don't get me wrong, the combat isn't unplayable or unfun, it's just nothing particularly special. This is not a AAA FPS.

It's also worthy to note that, when this game was first released, it had several game-breaking bugs. However, the vast majority of the bugs have been mopped up now, and I have had no trouble since the first few patches they released to fix the major bugs.

reviewText:
They tried to break the fourth wall so hard, they actually broke the game...
+ Combat. That's where the game really shines! It will throw more bugs at you than Donkey Kong ever threw barrels at Mario and you will find yourself fighting the game itself. That's a pretty unique feature!
+ Replayability. Each PC gets a different set of bugs to deal with, depending at least on your videocard. Each player gets a unique playthrough! Isn't that innovative? And yeah, branching plot.
+ Adequate length. Each playthrough takes about two hours (not counting the time you spend fighting bugs) to ensure you can try everything out and have a set of saves for the second game. Did I mention dialogues can't be skipped?
+ Plot. You can make a dozen of different decisions without being able to see the consequences of half of them (unless you buy the two upcoming games).
In all seriousness, this game has a pretty interesting and branching story. So, if you are ready to face numerous bugs, you should play it. It is completable, but bugs may mess up your experience.

reviewText:
This has the potential to be a great game series in the same vein as mass effect.

Unfortunately this first game is quite short and very rough around the edges. The game systems look like they have a lot of potential, but most of it is wasted given that you'll spend the vast majority of your time in this short game wandering around the plane talking to people. There is very little combat outside of the in-game simulator so you never really get to take advantage of the combat system at all. The story just kind of ends rather abruptly right when you think the game is about to really get going.

This game has options for using a gamepad on the main menu, but not all of the in-game menus support the controller (most notably the inventory), and some critical buttons aren't even mapped so you still need a keyboard to play the game.

The silver lining in all this is that they're already working on what is episode 2 to continue the story and hopefully start realizing the potential of what they have here.

Given the reasonable price and the potential of this series, I can tentatively recommend it, but be aware that this feels very much like an unfinished game.

reviewText: A real surprise, funny, witty, you can spend hours playing whatever character/mood you want with numerous timed dialogs. The timing on the answers avoid those tedious conversation mini-maxing and you just play whatever you fancy and to hell with the consequences. Somehow, after a small session I'm already enjoying the story, the gameplay and the overall experience better that a Mass Effect or equivalent AAA titles. Bring back the souvenirs of the good time I had playing Space Quest or Days of the Tentacle.

reviewText:
Looking at screenshots, I didn't expect much from this game.
I could not have been more wrong. Quite possibly one of the best games I've ever played.

An interesting concept which seems a little silly at first, but after only a few minutes of actual play you'll be totally immersed in the whole idea behind it. Not to mention the rich and highly developed setting.
The whole experience is very head first. There's little telling you were to go or who anyone is, or even any names. Freedom is given entirely to you to figure out everything about the whole experience, no annoying HUD popups telling you everything. I love it.

If you like role playing, this game is for you. I struggle to think of many finer examples.

If like me, you're looking at screenshots and thinking it looks a bit crap, trust me; Try it. The plasticy looking environments and people are perfectly suited to the entire lore of the game.

I hope you enjoy as much as I am right now.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I adore this game. It's difficult to find much wrong with it now that they've meticulously patched it, fixing all the performance issues and irritating bugs.
This is possibly the first game I've played where the characters seem like real people with real relationships that really matter. You feel as though you're really leaving an impression on them as you attempt to solve the myriad mysteries of Zenlil, the futuristic plane, while a conspiracy of powers you can't hope to understand weaves its web below the surface. I'm even a big fan of the graphic style, which brings back nostalgic memories of 90s CG television shows like Reboot. Who knew flat-shaded textures could have such a charm to them?
While it wraps itself in the guise of a first-person-shooter, Consortium is a conversational game first and foremost, with almost every encounter with danger solvable without needing to resort to circle-strafing and machine-gunning. As such it can be a more sedate experience than you're comfortable with if you're looking for a more conventional FPS. I'd very much recommend it to people who are more inclined towards adventure games and other more story-based genres.
With how open-ended the game is and how many ways you can alter and affect the timeline, I reckon I'll be giving Consortium a bunch more playthroughs before the next installment.
A+ - Very Recommended.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Interactive media and motion picture had a baby.  CONSORTIUM is an outstanding example of how immersive storytelling can be accomplished, with decisions and impacts that really matter.

A quick example: forgetting to charge your energy reserves before meeting with your boss can determine whether or not a crew member dies....  Not because it's scripted that way, but because you have to run to need energy reserves in order to inject a wounded crew member with healing nanites.  And if you aren't prepared, they bleed out before you get back.

There are numerous other instances that truly inspire that this game is indeed another universe, that the characters are living, coping, and otherwise dealing with the stress of being in a tense military situation.

Sadly, the graphics do not live up to this - The game went for a slightly cartoony look instead of a realistic look.  That said, it works well with the chosen art style, and it isn't the visual art that makes the game.  It's the audio, the writing, and the humanoid interactions and reactions.

The game is a little short for what I was hoping (was able to fully complete 1 variant of the story in 2 hours), but it has quite a bit of variation and replayability based on what you do and don't do.

TL;DR - Highly recommended if you want a story-driven adventure game that doesn't rely on logic puzzles or item gimmicks.  Plus, its story is awesomely meta.

reviewText:
EDITED BELOW
I am quite upset with this game. I helped with testing the game and giving feedback to the developers hoping to improve the game to a playiable state, and they have done significant patches which have helped allot. However, the game is still broken.

Issues:
- Allot of crashes related to the User Interface (moving items in and around your inventory) making the game unplayiable untill this issue is resolved
- Clipping issues
- And more crashes

Pros:
- Excellent voice acting and setting, I cannot believe the amount of options and intereaction between NPC's. It is truely amasing!
- Great feel to the game

Conclusion:
This game is not ready for release. The Dev's are working hard to resolve the issues and are doing a great job. However the game is still broken. I'd only reccomend purchasing this game if you can handle allot of crashes or if you are going to try and help the Devs.

My rating of the game in its current state:
3/10

My rating of the game ignoring the crashes:
9/10

EDIT: The bugs are fixed and this game is amazing! Very good job considering the amount of work the developers have put in. A solid 9/10

reviewText:
I was pleasantly surprised at how encompassing the world is. The backstory is super fleshed out and very captivating. It's like a sci-fi 'choose-your-own-adventure novel' video game, with guns, and a murder mystery. Definitely unlike anything I've ever played before, and I mean that in the best way possible.

The art style is different. It's almost cartooney-looking and the shadows look really bad. Which I wouldn't mind but although the textures and all around graphical quality is sub-par, the game is very gpu intensive at random points in-game. I'm playing with a r9 380 at 1080 and some instances such as a terminal displaying a hologram would drop my frame rate from 60+ to -30 fps.

The actual shooting mechanics aren't great, but they aren't a huge part of the game. Consortium is definitely a story-driven adventure game with fps elements. In my story, I only experienced combat twice outside the training sequences.

The story is pretty short in lenth, but rich with substance and a high replayability value. All-around, I thoroughly enjoyed this game and I'm eager to continue the adventure.
